page.title: 13WILDLIFE
page.content: This is an intensively farmed and densely populated area,and has been so for many centuries.As a result many of the larger forms of wildlife have disappeared and many others are under threat,from such things as pesticides and population pressure.However the Queen Elizabeth Country Park wardens work hard to preserve the local wildlife ,especially that associated with the chalk downlands.This includes plants such as the cowslip, insects like the yellow meadow ant, butterflies such as the chalkhill blue ,reptiles including the adder and various lizards and mammals like the roe dear.It is of interest to note that the hot summer of 1984 produced an extraordinarily large number of adders and that the rabbit population is once again beginning to reach large numbers.
